speaker: Bob
text: So how do you know Kirby?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I was his, uh, tutor.

speaker: Bob
text: Yow, how much do I owe you for that?

speaker: Frasier
text: It was a pleasure really.  So you're Kirby's dad?  Lana's ex who ran off with the dental hygienist.

speaker: Bob
text: [_unoffended_] But you can call me Bob.  I take it Lana filled you in about our divorce?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I was a shoulder for her briefly.  You know, I think she's completely over you now.

speaker: Bob
text: I hope not!  I mean I really want her back.  I'll do whatever it takes to show her I'm a changed man.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, Bob, I-I don't think that's a very good idea.

speaker: Bob
text: Well, but you said at the airport...

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I know, I... [_seeing an opportunity to divert Bob's attention_] Oh, Roz! Roz, listen, I'd like you to meet, uh, Bob. Bob, this is Roz Doyle, the brilliant producer of my radio show.

speaker: Roz
text: Gee, thanks, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, beauty and brains, huh? Ha, ha.  Who said God doesn't give with both hands, huh? [_Encouragingly_] And, Roz, I believe, if I'm not mistaken you're, uh, available right now?

speaker: Roz
text: [_Interested_] Maybe.  So what brings you to this little soiree?

speaker: Bob
text: Well, I'm Kirby's dad and Lana's ex, although hopefully not for long.  Thanks to this man, I've decided to follow my heart and come back to the woman I really love.

speaker: Roz
text: [_realizing Frasier's motivation_] Oh, really? [_She walks toward Frasier._] _Kirby and Lana enter from the kitchen.  Kirby is covering Lana's eyes as they walk out._

speaker: Lana
text: Kirby, what is it?

speaker: Kirby
text: You'll see.  You'll see. _Kirby removes his hand from Lana's eyes.  She sees Bob and is immediately filled with disgust._

speaker: Lana
text: OH, CRAP!! [_She runs directly to her bedroom._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, there goes that.  You gave it your best try Bob.  In the words of Tennyson... [_Bob has run to Lana's bedroom._] Bob?  Damn.

speaker: Roz
text: [_Hits Frasier in the chest._] You jerk!  I am not just some man bait that you can just set out whenever it suits you!

speaker: Frasier
text: I know, I'm sorry Roz.  I was desperate.  For God's sake, I just ended things with Claire and now I'm here to pursue Lana and then _he_ shows up.  Everything's ruined!

speaker: Lana
text: [_yelling from the bedroom_] Why don't you just leave?!  You're good at that!  Just go!

speaker: Bob
text: [_emerging from the bedroom_] I'll call you later, son.

speaker: Kirby
text: You can't quit now! If you're going to come back, you got to get used to her screaming! [_Exits._]

speaker: Roz
text: You know, as ugly as that was, things couldn't have worked out any better for you.  I mean, she's vulnerable, there's a full bar, she's already in the bedroom.  Almost takes the sport out of it. [_She takes a drink._]

speaker: Frasier
text: I know you must be upset, Kirby.

speaker: Kirby
text: The guy just wants to talk to her and she gets completely bent.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know.

speaker: Kirby
text: I know it's a cliche, okay.  I just, I really want my parents to get back together.

speaker: Frasier
text: I wish I could help.

speaker: Kirby
text: You could talk to my mother.  You could tell her to give him another chance.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I, I don't think I'm the guy for that job.

speaker: Kirby
text: Talking to people _is_ your job.  You could try.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I can't.

speaker: Kirby
text: Can't?  I seem to recall a young pupil named Kirby.  He said "I can't" nary but months ago.  But a certain man named Dr. Frasier Crane taught that pupil that he can do whatever he sets his mind to.  And the name of that man was YOU! _CUT TO: Lana's Bedroom.  Lana is lying on her bed in a prone position, obviously very distressed. Frasier is heard knocking on the door from the outside.  Frasier enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Bob's left.  Are you all right?

speaker: Lana
text: I have waited over a year for that man to come back to me, and when I finally get to the point where I never want to see him again, he walks through the door!

speaker: Frasier
text: But you're... you're much stronger now.  It'd take a lot more than just showing up to change your mind.

speaker: Lana
text: Well, to be fair, he did try to apologize.  I mean, what else can he do?  He can't take the whole last year back.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, he can't.

speaker: Lana
text: Can I ask you something?  In your opinion as a psychiatrist, once you've lost trust, can you ever get it back?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_struggling_] Well, it would take work...a lot of work. Think about it, Lana. [_He takes her hand._] You could have a whole new life now.

speaker: Lana
text: I could.  I'm just so confused.  Frasier, you are the only man I can trust right now.  Tell me what to do. _She is very vulnerable.  If Frasier made his move now, he would probably have her.  He caresses her hand, obviously struggling with his ethics.  As usual, his ethics win._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... the truth is... that you wouldn't be having this crisis if you didn't still have feelings for Bob.  You should talk to him.  You owe it to yourself to hear him out.

speaker: Lana
text: I just want you to know, Frasier, that no matter what happens, you are a really good...

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't... Don't use the F-word.

speaker: Lana
text: I wasn't about to! [_Playfully tapping his shoulder._] I was going to say we're friends! _Lana laughs and collapses on the bed.  Frasier rubs her back, the tension now gone.  FADE TO:  Scene 2 - Frasier's apartment. Niles, Martin, and Daphne are seated at the dinner table._

speaker: Martin
text: Great pot roast, Daph.

speaker: Daphne
text: Wow, thanks Mr. Crane.  I used turnips and pearl onions for the...

speaker: Martin
text: [_giving up_] Oh, what's the use?  This place will never be the same without Claire.

speaker: Niles
text: We all miss her, Dad.

speaker: Daphne
text: No one misses her more than me.  She could have been the sister I never had.

speaker: Martin
text: You think we can call her?

speaker: Daphne
text: What would we say?

speaker: Niles
text: She's probably out on a date with somebody else.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, maybe not.  Let's just see if she's home. _Martin rises and moves to the telephone.  Niles and Daphne follow. Martin dials._

speaker: Niles
text: Put it on speaker.

speaker: Martin
text: You do the talking.

speaker: Niles
text: No, Daphne should.

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't know what to say! _Claire answers: "Hello?"  They all stand stupefied.  Claire again says "Hello."  Martin hangs up in panic, and all three rush back to their chairs._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, that was childish.

speaker: Niles
text: She star 69'd us.  Don't answer it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you all gone deaf?  Isn't someone going to answer that?

speaker: Martin
text: You're up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello?... Claire!... I did not call you, you called me!  I did not! I did not!  I did...

speaker: Frasier
text: What was that all about?

speaker: Martin
text: Beats me, she always was a little nutty.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, how did things go with Lana?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think she's going back with her ex-husband.  He showed up at the party, and I ended up counseling her to give him a second chance. [_He sits on the couch._] It was the noble thing to do... although my honor won't keep me warm at night.

speaker: Martin
text: Guess it just wasn't meant to be.

speaker: Daphne
text: But don't give up!  There's a lid for every pot. [_She stands and moves to Niles, who puts his arm around her._]

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm, that's right.  Good things come to those who wait.

speaker: Martin
text: And there are plenty of fish in the sea.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God!  I will choke on another platitude!  Please!  Can't you say something helpful for once?!

speaker: Martin
text: [_fed up_] Well, I'm sorry if the material isn't fresh anymore! It isn't easy coming up with happy talk every time you can't make it work with a woman!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_incredulous_] "Every time I can't make it work with a woman"?!

speaker: Martin
text: That's right!  We wouldn't be in this situation if you hadn't blown it with Claire!

speaker: Frasier
text: Is that so?! [_to Niles and Daphne_] Do you all feel this way?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll clear.

speaker: Niles
text: I'll help.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_wounded_] I see.  My own family has turned on me in my darkest hour!  After a day of personal torment, I stagger homeward chapfallen... _Martin waves his hand and follows Niles and Daphne.  Frasier has turned away and doesn't see this._

speaker: Frasier
text: ...in search of comfort in the bosom of my family, but do they indulge me and permit me to suckle?  No, instead they... _He turns and sees that they have all left the room during his tirade. He pauses._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I've said my piece. _Frasier exits with a sense of just indignation.  FADE TO:_ **HEAD TRIP** _Scene 3 - Frasier's car. Frasier is driving when his cell phone rings.  He answers it._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello?  Yes, hi, Niles.  Listen, I'm fine, actually.  I, I just need a little time alone.  I'll, I'll see you in a day or two. No, there's no need to put Dad on.  He's already "consoled" me enough as it is.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Every time I can't make it work with a woman"!  What the hell does he know?

speaker: Lilith
text: [_o.s._] He's not wrong, Frasier. _The remainder of this scene, as well as the first scene of Act 4, are an extended fantasy within Frasier's mind.  We now see Lilith in the passenger seat._

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, he is!  It wasn't that I couldn't make it work with Lana. I simply stepped aside when the father of her _children_ showed up, like the decent human being I am.

speaker: Lilith
text: And - speaking on behalf of your subconscious - because you realized the relationship was destined to fail.

speaker: Frasier
text: And why would that be?  Lana could've been perfect for me.

speaker: Lilith
text: Is that just something you say out of habit now?

speaker: Frasier
text: No!

speaker: Lilith
text: Because two weeks ago the title belonged to Claire.

speaker: Frasier
text: Claire was perfect.  I just wasn't in love with her.  The heart has a mind of its own, they say.

speaker: Lilith
text: Or perhaps she wasn't needy enough for you.  You have been known to love a project.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, please!  I have never found neediness to be an attractive quality in a woman!

speaker: Diane
text: Never?

speaker: Frasier
text: Never!  Neediness was the very reason it _didn't_ work with Diane!  Specifically her need... for another man.

speaker: Lilith
text: But you were attracted to her initially because her weakness allowed you to play the role of noble rescuer.

speaker: Diane
text: Excuse me, I have to object to the word "weakness."  I was challenging, yet vulnerable, which is why Frasier saw me as the perfect woman for him, still does.

speaker: Frasier
text: I do not.

speaker: Diane
text: Then why am I in the car?

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps you represent a happier time in my life.

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier, do you remember the time we drove down the cape and had a lobster picnic on the bluff? [_turning to Lilith_] We had nothing to crack open the claws, so Frasier put them in a bag and ran over them with the car!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_chuckles_] That didn't work either.

speaker: Diane
text: [_laughs nostalgically_] Oh, we gave up and made glorious love in the dunes.  Hmmm...

speaker: Lilith
text: Wait a minute.  Wasn't that me?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_thinks_] Right, that was you.

speaker: Diane
text: Well then, what _do_ I represent?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know and I don't care.  Now if you don't mind, I'd like a little peace.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear God, not her!

speaker: Diane
text: That person's not wearing shoes!

speaker: Lilith
text: That's Nanette.  His first wife.

speaker: Diane
text: She's going to get hookworm!

speaker: Lilith
text: He's obviously dredging up past relationships in order to identify a pattern.

speaker: Diane
text: [_smiles_] Why, Frasier Crane, you were a hippie!

speaker: Frasier
text: I was 20! That was during my impulsive, rebellious phase. _'60's style folk guitar music begins to be heard.  It can be seen out the window that Nanette is carrying a guitar._

speaker: Diane
text: [_sympathetically_] Oh, pick her up! You can't ignore her.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's not a part of who I am anymore! _Nanette appears in the back seat next to Diane, strumming her guitar. She has arrived directly from the late '60's/early '70's and is a stereotypical hippie/flower child._

speaker: Nanette
text: Do you remember that song?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_horrified_] Apparently, I do.

speaker: Nanette
text: He composed it in college. It's how we met.  He wrote it as a poem and was reciting it one night at the Human Collective when I joined in with my guitar.  Would you like to hear it?

speaker: Frasier
text: NO!!

speaker: Lilith/Diane
text: Oh, yes!/Yes, please!

speaker: Nanette
text: It's called "Bangladesh: Dhaka before the dawn." [_She begins to sing._] "I dreamt that I was riding a candy unicorn / As I went to meet my lady in the dewdrop crystal morn..."

speaker: Frasier
text: The Bangladesh part's coming. [_N.B. Since Bangladesh gained independence from Pakistan in 1971, this must be roughly when Frasier and Nanette met, which seems right based on Frasier's current age._]  _End of Act 3  ACT 4  Scene 4 - The Crane family cabin. It is the cabin last seen in[[7.01]](/frasier/transcripts/season_7/episode_1/momma_mia.html "Momma Mia"), "Momma Mia."  Frasier enters. _

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh... Solitude.  This is what I needed!

speaker: Diane
text: Perhaps.  But to quote Lord Byron, "It is in solitude where we are least alone."

speaker: Lilith
text: Smells like dirt out there. [_seeing the cabin's interior_] Whoa!

speaker: Nanette
text: Before Frasier sold out, we always dreamed of having a home like this - where we'd be surrounded by nature and need only the food that we grew and the shelter of each other's arms.

speaker: Lilith
text: [_drily_] It's amazing that marriage didn't work out.

speaker: Diane
text: [_aside to Lilith_] She was probably great in the sack.

speaker: Nanette
text: Actually, I made a lot of distracting noises.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, all right. [_closes door_] This has been a lot of fun, but what's it going to take to get you people out of my head?

speaker: Lilith
text: Well, a little self-examination might do it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine!  I'm a failure in love. [_throws a bag into the kitchen/ pantry_] I failed with all of you.  I failed with Lana and with Claire, and with countless others in between.  Happy?

speaker: Lilith
text: Failure is a result, not a cause.  What's at the core?

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps there _is_ no core.  Maybe fate's just conspiring against me.  Did you ever think of that?

speaker: Lilith
text: No, there's no such thing as fate.

speaker: Nanette
text: [_now knitting on the couch_] Ha!  If that were true, there'd be no such thing as astrology!

speaker: Lilith
text: [_glancing dismissively at Nanette_] More avoidance, Frasier. Try to focus!

speaker: Diane
text: I just had a thought! [_Frasier approaches her, listening eagerly._] Maybe it isn't Frasier's fault.

speaker: Lilith
text: Oh, denial, how nice to see you. [_Frasier glares at her._]

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm?

speaker: Diane
text: It's your women!  We leave you.  It's in our nature.  I left you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  You did!  You left me for Sam.

speaker: Diane
text: [_dreamily_] I left Sam, too.

speaker: Lilith
text: Diane, we're talking about Frasier.  When we're inside _your_ head, we'll talk about you. _Diane is now wearing a painter's smock, holding a paint-covered palette, and working on an unfinished portrait on an easel.  The portrait is of Sam Malone._

speaker: Diane
text: I'm just saying that his women leave. [_to Lilith_] You did, too.

speaker: Nanette
text: So did I!

speaker: Frasier
text: That's right!  You all did.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, and poor Frasier.  You keep on trying.

speaker: Nanette
text: He can't help it!  He's a hopeless romantic.

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier, when are you going to learn? [_sings_] "Falling in love with love is falling for make-believe..."

speaker: Nanette
text: What's wrong with following your heart?  Just because we left him doesn't mean the perfect woman isn't out there somewhere.

speaker: Lilith
text: That's the problem.  Frasier thinks every woman is the perfect woman until he finds the deal-breaking flaw. [_distracted by Diane's singing_] You-, we... [_to Frasier_] Can you make that stop?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry.  It's stuck in my head.

speaker: Diane
text: [_singing_] "I realized that I was unable to sing..."

speaker: Lilith
text: Thank you. [_Diane looks put upon._] It's that quest for perfection which ultimately defeats you, because the perfect woman does not exist.

speaker: Hester
text: [_o.s._] Speak for yourself!

speaker: Frasier
text: MOTHER!

speaker: Hester
text: [_referencing the three women_] For such a short trip, you sure brought a lot of _baggage_!

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Lilith
text: You have to ask?  You're a Freudian.

speaker: Hester
text: You've spent your whole life trying to replace me, but it's completely understandable.  I was your first love.

speaker: Lilith
text: Ladies, meet the competition. [_indicating Hester_] This is the woman against whom we have all been measured.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_interrupting her_] Lilith, will you please be quiet!  Mother is speaking!

speaker: Hester
text: So, a lifetime of collecting women and this is the cream of the crop: the slacker, the barmaid, and the icicle.  I was so relieved when they left you.

speaker: Diane
text: _You_ left him too!

speaker: Hester
text: Oh, I had no choice.  Perhaps you heard?  I died.  Now, let's get down to work, shall we? [_moves to the couch_]

speaker: Lilith
text: We were doing perfectly well before you got here.

speaker: Hester
text: Well, if your bargain-basement psychiatry was so effective, why did he have to call in the big guns? [_sits_] Now, let's explore the inner recesses of your psyche like we did when you were a boy. [_indicates her knee_]

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't want to! _As Hester begins to speak, Frasier approaches the couch, lies on it, and puts his head on Hester's lap._

speaker: Hester
text: Perhaps we should start with the premise set forth in the definitive study done by Harlan and Watkins.

speaker: Lilith
text: Oh, excuse me, but the definitive study was done ten years later at Cambridge.

speaker: Hester
text: Oh, excuse me for not keeping up.  I was busy being _dead!_

speaker: Nanette
text: That's her excuse for everything!

speaker: Hester
text: Don't you have a tambourine to bang?

speaker: Diane
text: Don't feel bad.  She tried to kill me once.

speaker: Hester
text: Oh, not this paranoia again!

speaker: Diane
text: You had a gun.

speaker: Hester
text: Frasier, don't listen to them.  These women are all liars and cheaters.  I'm the only woman you can trust.

speaker: Diane
text: You're a fine one to talk!  You cheated on Martin.

speaker: Hester
text: Oh, that's none of your beeswax, Missy!

speaker: Lilith
text: Oh, betrayal by the mother.  Is there any deeper wound?

speaker: Hester
text: [_stands_] I'd say sleeping with his _brother_ is right up there!

speaker: Diane
text: [_gasps, to Lilith_] You did?!

speaker: Hester
text: Mmm-hmm!

speaker: Diane
text: [_fantasizing_] Ooh, I could see _that._

speaker: Diane
text: Don't even _think_ about my baby like that!

speaker: Nanette
text: You can't control her thoughts.

speaker: Hester
text: Oh, shut up, you're a whore.

speaker: Nanette
text: [_stands_] You're a hypocrite!

speaker: Hester
text: Whore!

speaker: Nanette
text: Hypocrite!

speaker: Hester
text: Whore!

speaker: Nanette
text: Hypocrite!  You're all hypocrites!

speaker: Hester
text: And you're all whores!

speaker: Lilith
text: Stop it!  Stop it!  Stop it!  Don't you see what he's doing? He's pitting us against each other in order to avoid the real conflict within himself.  We must work together. _The others respond with "Right," "I agree," etc.  They converge on Frasier._

speaker: Hester
text: What is the problem?  Why can't you make it work with a woman?

speaker: Diane
text: Is it because they leave you?

speaker: Nanette
text: Have you stopped listening to your heart?

speaker: Lilith
text: Is it your unrealistic expectations?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know. [_gets off the couch and runs to the door_] Leave me alone!  I don't want to do this! _He opens the door and gasps.  There is a score of women crowded in the doorway.  "Hi, Frasier," they all say.  He closes the door behind him in a state of utter panic._

speaker: Diane
text: What is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's every woman I've ever dated!  [_N.B. Well, not quite.  However, all of the women in the door were actual actresses who had played Frasier's various love interests over the entire course of the show.  All of them were brought to the set to appear for these three seconds.  For their identities and the episodes in which they appeared, see the "Guest Cast" above._]

speaker: Frasier
text: What am I going to do?

speaker: Hester
text: Now, son.  I know this is frightening for you, but you have to do the work.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gives in_] Okay... [_walks back to the center of the room_] Okay. [_sits on the couch_] Fine.  All right.  I screwed things up with Lana.  But wait, that wasn't my fault.  She was still in love with her ex-husband.

speaker: Lilith
text: No, Lana is not the problem.

speaker: Hester
text: No, she wasn't right for you at all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, mother, you would say that.  You never approved of any of my relationships.

speaker: Hester
text: Don't pin this on me.  I liked Claire.

speaker: Diane
text: Oh, she _was_ perfect for you.

speaker: Nanette
text: Everybody thought so.

speaker: Hester
text: So why didn't it work out?

speaker: Lilith
text: Maybe because she _was_ just right for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: What does _that_ mean?

speaker: Hester
text: Well, Claire was everything we ever looked for in a woman.

speaker: Lilith
text: And that terrified you.

speaker: Diane
text: Because inevitably she would have left you.

speaker: Nanette
text: And so, of course, you ran away.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no.  I left Claire because I discovered I had feelings for Lana.

speaker: Lilith
text: You _created_ feelings for Lana...

speaker: Hester
text: Who was extremely flawed...

speaker: Lilith
text: So you'd have an excuse to leave Claire.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but I didn't need an excuse.  I didn't love her!

speaker: Lilith
text: You didn't _want_ to love her.

speaker: Hester
text: She was too good.

speaker: Diane
text: And that's why you were afraid.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, you're saying that I'm afraid of a good woman?

speaker: Hester
text: You're afraid of _losing_ a good woman.  Again.

speaker: Frasier
text: So that's it... all this work, just to find out that I have a fear of rejection?

speaker: Lilith
text: That's right.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_beside himself_] So I'm alone... because I'm afraid to be alone?!

speaker: Diane
text: Don't feel too bad.  You'll always have us.  Isn't that right, girls?

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, wait a minute! _They become silent.  Frasier now has a tremendous moment of revelation. He rises and paces the room._

speaker: Frasier
text: That's it!  That's my problem.  _You_ are always there.  I have carried you with me throughout every relationship, on every date.  You pick apart every woman I care about and you remind me how much it'll hurt if I open myself up.  You don't help me. You hold me back.  How will I ever move forward if I don't put _He looks behind him.  The four women have all disappeared.  He looks around again, realizes that his epiphany was real, and smiles.  FADE TO:  Scene 5 - Frasier's apartment. Fade in to reveal Niles and Martin getting ready to go out._

speaker: Niles
text: Hurry along, Daphne, we'll miss the curtain.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, and you know how strict they are about that at the Cineplex.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sorry.  I was rushing and I put my heel through the hem of my skirt, so I had to put on another one.

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh, it looks nice.

speaker: Daphne
text: Then the top didn't go, so I changed it to this, but I couldn't wear this with a black brassiere, so I had to change that, which meant I had to change me knickers to match in case I go to the hospital. [_Niles and Martin exchange a glance._] You know, coordinating undergarments are the mark of a lady and all that.  Anyway, it's a long story.  I won't bore you with it.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sarcastically_] Yeah, thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey.

speaker: Martin
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, guys.

speaker: Daphne
text: How are you, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, I'm-I'm fine, Daphne.  In fact, my little retreat was just what this doctor ordered.  I cleared my head.  Came to some conclusions.  So where are you guys off to?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, just one of Dad's movies.  You want to join us?  I brought my "Itty-Bitty Book Light."

speaker: Frasier
text: No thanks, you guys go ahead.

speaker: Daphne
text: You'll be okay, won't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes, I'll be just fine.

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't I just stay here to keep you company?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, really Dad, I'm fine.

speaker: Martin
text: You sure?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  In fact, I'm...I'm better than I've been in quite some time.  Mainly because of one very important thing I learned...

speaker: Martin
text: [_interrupting_] Great!  Let's roll. _The three of them exit quickly.  Clearly they have no desire to hear about the "very important thing."  Frasier doesn't care.  He grins widely and collapses on his couch, more content than we have seen him in a very long time.  FADE OUT_ **In loving memory of our friends Lynn and David Angell**
